Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation2: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s name flashing on the screen. Her text was desperate: “Can you come over? I really need you.” She never asked for help unless it was serious. I knew she was struggling after her breakup, and being there for each other was what we always promised. But as I glanced at my laptop, the unfinished report glared back at me. The deadline was tonight, and my part was crucial for the team. If I didn’t finish, the next person couldn’t start, and the whole project would be delayed. I could already imagine the disappointment in my manager’s voice and the frustration of my teammates. My heart twisted, torn between the sister who needed me and the colleague everyone was counting on. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down, each demanding more than I could give. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, paralyzed, as I tried to decide which promise I would have to break.
